item.title: Automating Your Workflow: From GitHub Commits to Netlify Deployments
item.description: Introduction Link to heading In today’s fast-paced development environment, automating your deployment pipeline is essential for maintaining productivity and reducing manual errors. This guide will walk you through setting up an automated workflow that commits your code to GitHub and automatically deploys it to Netlify. Why Automate Your Deployment? Link to heading Before diving into the technical details, let’s understand why automation matters: Consistency: Every deployment follows the same process Speed: Instant deployments on code changes Reliability: Reduced human error in deployment process Scalability: Handle multiple projects efficiently Rollback capability: Easy to revert problematic deployments Prerequisites Link to heading Before we begin, ensure you have:

item.title: Robots.txt
item.description: Added enableRobotsTXT = true to the config.toml file And: [params.robots] noindex = true Added robots.txt to the static folder with: User-agent: * Disallow: /

item.title: Google Analytics
item.description: Added the following to config.toml to setup Google Analytics: [params.googleTagManager] id = “id…”

item.title: Setup Replit for my new blog
item.description: So I read this link to help me setup Replit to use Hugo. Build and host your company blog on Replit with Nix and Hugo - DEV Community Open `replit.nix` and append `pkgs.hugo`to the `deps` list In the shell, run: hugo new site --force . cd themes && git clone https://github.com/panr/hugo-coder && cd .. Add the following line to the bottom of `config.toml`: theme = 'hugo-coder' Add: run = "hugo server --buildDrafts --buildFuture --bind 0.

item.title: About
item.description: Currently, working on my new blog.
